results.abstract: Dr Lonnie Hammargren, former two-term Nevada lieutenant governor and retired neurosurgeon, packs three-level home with thousands of bits of memorabilia and lifetime of acquisitions; opens home to public every year to observe anniversary of Nevada statehood; career highlights; photos (M)

headline.main: House Packed With Stuff Is Annual Draw in Nevada

results.snippet: The Castillo del Sol, the Hammargren Home of Nevada History and the Principality of Paradise are the three names used for a home in Nevada that houses a collection of things.
results.lead_paragraph: Sandy Hammargren is the definition of a patient, long-suffering wife, except when it comes to Big Bertha. Her husband, Dr. Lonnie Hammargren, built Big Bertha, a black 10-foot-tall model locomotive, in their backyard from a disparate collection of parts: a rail car believed to have brought Howard Hughes to Las Vegas, part of a road girder, a piece of an 1890 steam tractor, a boiler ''from something entirely different, I can't remember what,'' Dr. Hammargren said. The wheels were from castoff parts of old CAT scan machines.

results.abstract: NASA is preparing for mission on space shuttle Endeavour to deliver spare toilet and system for recycling water to International Space Station; equipment is part of agency's plan to double station's crew size to six in 2009 (M)

headline.main: Space Plumbers Ready for Shuttle Launching

results.snippet: If all goes as planned, a team of intrepid space plumbers and lube-job specialists will lift off on Friday for a visit to the International Space Station.
results.lead_paragraph: If all goes as planned, a team of intrepid space plumbers and lube-job specialists will lift off on Friday for a visit to the International Space Station. Like all recent missions, this trip is mainly devoted to completing the $100 billion orbiting laboratory. The equipment heading skyward on the shuttle Endeavour is part of NASA's plan to double the station's crew size to six next year.

headline.main: Handyman to Return to His Space Workshop

results.snippet: Donald R. Pettit calls the International Space Station his “home away from home” and will be returning on the space shuttle Endeavour’s latest trip.
results.lead_paragraph: When the space shuttle Endeavour lifts off, it will be taking Donald R. Pettit back to the place he calls his ''home away from home'' -- the International Space Station. Mr. Pettit was serving five and a half months aboard the station in 2003 when the shuttle Columbia was lost over Texas. His duties during this mission, scheduled for liftoff at 7:55 p.m. on Friday, include operating the robotic arms of the station and shuttle, and transferring cargo onto the station that the shuttle brought up from Earth. Among the astronaut corps, Mr. Pettit is known as a uncommonly gifted handyman who has rebuilt a jet engine in his garage workshop, and a guy who gets things done.

results.abstract: NASA's Habitability Design Center is at work on interior of first-generation mock-up of new lunar rover, 380 cubic feet of space in which two astronauts will have to sleep, prepare and eat meals, exercise, use a toilet, drive around lunar surface and conduct scientific research on mission lasting from two days to two weeks; photo (M)
results.snippet: Garrett Finney is helping to design a rover that will comfortably house two people in the absolute discomfort of outer space.
results.lead_paragraph: WITH ALL DUE RESPECT to Richard Branson, in space travel, when one guy getting up in the middle of the night to use the facilities without waking up his neighbor is considered a giant leap for design, we are still light years away from a first-class ticket to the moon. Just ask Garrett Finney. The former senior architect for NASA's Habitability Design Center, and now a consultant for NASA, is photographed here between Carl Conlee and Evan Twyford, two recent Rhode Island School of Design grads and full-time habitability-center designers, during the recent test run of a first-generation mock-up of a new rover. Working with their ''client,'' the astronaut Mike Gernhardt, as well as a team of about 25 NASA engineers, Conlee and Twyford are devising the interior of the module so that two people will be able to sleep, prepare and eat meals, exercise, use the facilities, drive around and conduct scientific research on missions lasting from two days to two weeks -- all in about 380 cubic feet. And you thought your apartment was small.

results.snippet: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) DIRECT FROM THE MOON The Apollo astronaut Buzz Aldrin watches breathtaking images of the Moon's craters and haunting plains, and observes an Earth-rise in this second ''Expedition Week''  installment. The episode looks at...
results.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) DIRECT FROM THE MOON The Apollo astronaut Buzz Aldrin watches breathtaking images of the Moon's craters and haunting plains, and observes an Earth-rise in this second ''Expedition Week'' installment. The episode looks at the Selene, a Japanese lunar orbiter custom-built to map the Moon's surface and measure its magnetic and gravitational fields. For the last year it has been beaming high-definition images back to Earth. NASA scientists discuss the challenges involved in and innovations under way for establishing a lunar outpost. 8 P.M. (CW) GOSSIP GIRL Cyrus (Wallace Shawn) disrupts the Waldorf family Thanksgiving traditions and upsets Blair (Leighton Meester) in the process. Lily (Kelly Rutherford) tries to broker peace between Rufus (Matthew Settle) and Jenny (Taylor Momsen). And Eric (Connor Paolo) uncovers something Bart (Robert John Burke) doesn't want him to know.

headline.main: Tool Bag Is Lost During Spacewalk

results.snippet: Astronauts ventured outside the International Space Station to do repair work, but lost a bag of tools they had taken along. Capt. Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper of the Navy, an astronaut on a mission to the station, was on the first spacewalk of the...
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts ventured outside the International Space Station to do repair work, but lost a bag of tools they had taken along. Capt. Heidemarie Stefanyshyn-Piper of the Navy, an astronaut on a mission to the station, was on the first spacewalk of the mission, which involves cleaning and greasing a balky rotary joint, when she discovered that a grease gun had erupted inside its tote bag. While she cleaned up that mess, the bag -- containing two grease guns, scrapers and other equipment -- floated irretrievably into space. NASA trains spacewalkers to tether and trap all objects they use, but it is not uncommon for the occasional bolt or single tool to be lost.

headline.main: Arduous Space Mission in the Homestretch

results.snippet: The shuttle Endeavour will separate from the International Space Station on Friday and will land as early as Sunday at 1:18 p.m., weather permitting.

byline.original: By JOHN SCHWARTZ; William Harwood contributed reporting

results.lead_paragraph: The ''coffee machine'' is perking along. The machine that is designed to recycle astronauts' sweat, urine and waste water into drinking water aboard the International Space Station seems to have gotten over its initial balkiness, thanks to round-the-clock analysis by engineers on the ground and a great deal of tinkering by astronaut handymen.

results.lead_paragraph: Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on NBC: In a speech this morning, Barack Obama said, "This isn't about big government or small government. It's about building a smarter government." When he heard this, President Bush said, "I get it. I get it. I'm leaving."
